unnormalised: The year was 2008. I remember the day results for the IIT-JEE came out. My friend, Rajesh Sharma, from Vidya Mandir Classes (VMC), Delhi, had secured a rank within the top 500. For us, that was the gold standard. Everyone in our friend circle was aiming for a similar feat, fuelled by countless hours at coaching centres.
normalised: The year was two thousand and eight. I remember the day results for the I-I-T hyphen J-E-E came out. My friend, Rajesh Sharma, from Vidya Mandir Classes (V-M-C), Delhi, had secured a rank within the top five hundred. For us, that was the gold standard. Everyone in our friend circle was aiming for a similar feat, fuelled by countless hours at coaching centres.

unnormalised: Back then, Kota was already becoming a household name for IIT aspirants. While Rajesh opted for IIT Delhi, many others packed their bags for Rajasthan. I remember my cousin, Aisha Khan, who scored 92% in her CBSE 12th boards, joined Bansal Classes in Kota. Her parents believed that the rigorous training there would be the key to her success.
normalised: Back then, Kota was already becoming a household name for I-I-T aspirants. While Rajesh opted for I-I-T Delhi, many others packed their bags for Rajasthan. I remember my cousin, Aisha Khan, who scored ninety two percent in her C-B-S-E twelfth boards, joined Bansal Classes in Kota. Her parents believed that the rigorous training there would be the key to her success.

unnormalised: The competition was fierce. Aisha used to tell me about the daily routine – lectures from 8 AM to 2 PM, followed by doubt-clearing sessions and self-study till late at night. Weekends were reserved for mock tests mirroring the actual IIT-JEE exam pattern. She even told me about specific teachers known for their innovative teaching methods, like 'HC Verma sir's concepts'.
normalised: The competition was fierce. Aisha used to tell me about the daily routine – lectures from eight A-M to two P-M, followed by doubt-clearing sessions and self-study till late at night. Weekends were reserved for mock tests mirroring the actual I-I-T hyphen J-E-E exam pattern. She even told me about specific teachers known for their innovative teaching methods, like 'H-C Verma sir's concepts'.

unnormalised: There were smaller, but equally impactful coaching centres sprouting up in almost every city. In Guwahati, Brilliant Tutorials was considered top-notch for medical aspirants. My neighbor’s son, Rohan, prepared for AIIMS entrance there, attending classes 6 days a week, often travelling 20 km each way. He’d proudly show off his neatly organized notes and stacks of reference books.

He’d proudly show off his neatly organized notes and stacks of reference books.

unnormalised: The pressure was immense. I recall one incident where a student from Aisha's coaching centre attempted suicide due to exam stress. The incident shook everyone, highlighting the dark side of the competitive environment. The coaching centres, despite offering counselling sessions, were often seen as factories churning out toppers, with little emphasis on mental well-being.

unnormalised: Even after securing good ranks, the struggles didn't end. Securing a seat in the desired branch was another hurdle. Aisha wanted Computer Science but ended up with Mechanical Engineering at IIT Roorkee. This led to a lot of frustration initially. She eventually adapted, but the initial disappointment lingered.

unnormalised: The landscape has changed drastically since then. Online coaching platforms like Byju's and Unacademy are now popular, offering personalized learning experiences. Many of these platforms claim a 30% improvement in test scores. But the essence of the preparation remains the same – dedication, hard work, and a relentless pursuit of excellence.

unnormalised: Looking back, I realise the role these coaching centres played in shaping our lives. They provided a structured environment, mentorship, and a platform to compete with the best. While the system had its flaws, it undoubtedly prepared many of us for the challenges of life beyond the classroom. Even now, when I see "JEE ADV 2024" posters, a wave of nostalgia washes over me, reminding me of those intense, transformative years.
